Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Versatile Pump-Probe Transient Absorption and Fluorescence Upconversion System
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Programs. Professor Piotr Piotrowiak from Rutgers University Newark and colleagues Edward Castner, Elena Galoppini, Jenny Lockhard and Kevin Belfield (New Jersey Institute of Technology) are acquiring a pump-probe transient absorption and fluorescence upconversion spectrometer system. This is a laser based system which enables the study of a wide range of laser phenomena that address significant challenges of social, environmental and economic importance. Research topics focus on solar energy research, renewable energy and green chemistry, photovoltaic materials, and biomarkers linked to human health. The instrumentation strengthens research and training at three institutions: Rutgers-Newark, Rutgers-New Brunswick and the New Jersey Institute of Technology.

This pump-probe transient absorption and fluorescence upconversion spectrometer system enhances research and education at all levels. It serves researcher who are testing the interplay between electron transfer and vibrational cooling in extended donor-acceptor arrays as well as those seeking understanding of ionic liquids. Research probing the fundamental relationship between molecular structure and nonlinear optical properties of chromophores also utilize this instrument. The spectrometer system is used to look for surface modification strategies and synthetic tools to understand interfacial charge separation and electron transfer dynamics. Researchers carry out mechanistic studies on photocatalytic properties of hybrid materials to unify nanoscience, coordination chemistry and catalysis. The spectrometer is important in seeking to unravel terrestrial surface photogeochemistry in the Archaen period.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The instrument is serving as a crucial tool for advanced studies on a variety of novel materials relevant to renewable energy, biomedical imaging and capture of greenhouse gases. In addition to enabling scientific discovery, the access to the laser system has provided unique training opportunities for PhD students and postdoctoral associates. The individual projects required interdisciplinary expertise and relied on extensive international collaborations with key partners at multiple universities in Japan, Spain, Italy, Ukraine and China. Several of these collaborations have spawned new projects and will continue in the future.

Among the notable accomplishments by Rutgers University - Newark users of the instrument is the spectroscopic demonstration of the capture of "hot electrons" generated by visible light interacting with noble metal (gold) particles. These energetic electrons have been show in the past to be able to drive chemical reactions but spectroscopic evidence for the capture at the interface between the metal molecules attached to the surface has been elusive. Experiments performed on the instrument funded by this NSF grant emplued custom-designed molecules chemically anchored to the metal surface and allowed to determine the maximum distance at which the capture of the short-lived high energy electrons is effective. In a related study, dendritic (tree-like) networks of molecules were used as the means to extend the lifetime of charges generated by photoexcitation by several orders of magnitude by allowing the electrons randomly sample the branches of the network. The New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT) team of users focused on the characterization of both linear and nonlinear ultrafast photophysics of organic dyes (including cyanine dyes), dye-containing vesicles, novel heavy metal nanoparticles, along with polymer- and peptide-conjugated fluorophores, primarily in the context of biomedical applications. The significant milestones include successful regulation of mitochondrial pH with light by using novel photoacid generators, as well as the design and characterization of imaging dyes with peptide tethers capable of penetrating mitochondria, the crucial and complex sub-cellular structures responsible for providing cells with energy and controlling its overall life cycle.
